_**Are You Being Served?**_ is a [British sitcom](/wiki/British_sitcom
"British sitcom") created and written by [Jeremy Lloyd](/wiki/Jeremy_Lloyd
"Jeremy Lloyd") and [David Croft](/wiki/David_Croft_\(TV_producer\) "David
Croft \(TV producer\)") (Croft also directed some episodes), with
contributions from [Michael Knowles](/wiki/Michael_Knowles_\(actor\) "Michael
Knowles \(actor\)") and [John Chapman](/wiki/John_Chapman_\(English_writer\)
"John Chapman \(English writer\)"), for the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC").[2] Set in
London, the show follows the misadventures and mishaps of the staff of the
retail ladies' and gentlemen's clothing departments in the flagship
[department store](/wiki/Department_store "Department store") of a fictional
chain called Grace Brothers.

Broadcast between 1972 and 1985 on [BBC1](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One"), the sitcom
spanned ten series totaling 69 episodes – five of which are Christmas
specials. There was also [a 1977 film](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served%3F_\(film\)
"Are You Being Served? \(film\)"), [a follow-up series](/wiki/Grace_%26_Favour
"Grace & Favour") with some of the same main cast in 1991–92, and a one-off
episode with a new cast in 2016.

_Are You Being Served?_ was a great success in the UK and was also popular in
three other countries of the [Commonwealth of
Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") (Australia,
New Zealand, and Canada), and was successfully aired in The Netherlands and
Belgium with Dutch subtitles as well. The show was also popular in Israel and
in the United States, where it gained a loyal and enthusiastic following when
[PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") television stations began airing [reruns](/wiki/Rerun
"Rerun") of it in the mid-1980s, along with other [British
sitcoms](/wiki/British_sitcom "British sitcom"). In it was ranked 20th in the
countdown of _[Britain's Best Sitcom](/wiki/Britain%27s_Best_Sitcom "Britain's
Best Sitcom")_.[3] It is regularly repeated worldwide ([BBC Two](/wiki/BBC_Two
"BBC Two") in the UK, [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") and [BBC
America](/wiki/BBC_America "BBC America") in the United States; and [BBC
UKTV](/wiki/BBC_UKTV "BBC UKTV"), [Fox Classics](/wiki/Fox_Classics "Fox
Classics") and [9Go!](/wiki/9Go! "9Go!") in Australia.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The idea for the show came from Lloyd's brief period in the early 1950s
working at [Simpsons of Piccadilly](/wiki/Simpsons_of_Piccadilly "Simpsons of
Piccadilly"), a clothing store which traded for over 60 years until 1999.[4]
The inspiration for the store has also been credited to Rossiters of
[Paignton](/wiki/Paignton "Paignton") department store from the time Lloyd and
Croft spent there,[5] and the former Clements of [Watford](/wiki/Watford
"Watford").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Are_You_Being_Served_series_1_logo.svg/220px-
Are_You_Being_Served_series_1_logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Are_You_Being_Served_series_1_logo.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Are_You_Being_Served_series_1_logo.svg "Enlarge")

Logo used for series one

The [pilot episode](/wiki/Pilot_episode "Pilot episode") was created as part
of the _[Comedy Playhouse](/wiki/Comedy_Playhouse "Comedy Playhouse")_ series,
although the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") had originally chosen not to broadcast the
programme. The pilot was used as a filler during the [1972 Summer
Olympics](/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics "1972 Summer Olympics") when the coverage
of the Olympiad was interrupted by the [Munich massacre](/wiki/Munich_massacre
"Munich massacre") on 8 September 1972, leading to a full series being
produced.[6] This first episode was repeated at the beginning of the first
series on 14 March 1973. Although the first series was aired in the same
timeslot as _[Coronation Street](/wiki/Coronation_Street "Coronation Street")_
on [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)"), consequently
receiving relatively little attention, the repeats shown later in the year
were much more successful.[7]

The show became a ratings hit, and after a successful 13-year run, _Are You
Being Served?_ came to an end on 1 April 1985.

Of the original cast, only [Frank Thornton](/wiki/Frank_Thornton "Frank
Thornton"), [Mollie Sugden](/wiki/Mollie_Sugden "Mollie Sugden"), [John
Inman](/wiki/John_Inman "John Inman"), [Wendy Richard](/wiki/Wendy_Richard
"Wendy Richard") and [Nicholas Smith](/wiki/Nicholas_Smith_\(actor\) "Nicholas
Smith \(actor\)") appeared in all 69 episodes of the programme's 13-year run;
these five later featured in the sequel sitcom, _[Grace&
Favour](/wiki/Grace_%26_Favour "Grace & Favour")_ (also known as _Are You
Being Served? Again!_). The cast performed in character for a stage sketch on
the [BBC1](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One") programme _Variety_ on 19 June 1976.

Following the death of the last remaining original cast member, Nicholas
Smith, on 6 December 2015, the only surviving permanent cast members are [Mike
Berry](/wiki/Mike_Berry_\(actor\) "Mike Berry \(actor\)") as Mr Spooner,
[Candy Davis](/wiki/Candy_Davis "Candy Davis") (Miss Belfridge in the final
two seasons), [Penny Irving](/wiki/Penny_Irving "Penny Irving"), who played Mr
Grace's secretary Miss Bakewell between 1976 and 1979, and [Vivienne
Johnson](/wiki/Vivienne_Johnson "Vivienne Johnson"), who played both Young and
Old Mr Grace's nurse from 1977 to 1981. [Doremy Vernon](/wiki/Doremy_Vernon
"Doremy Vernon"), starring as feisty canteen manageress Diana Yardwick over
several seasons, also survives; however, she only appeared on a recurring
basis and was never part of the regular cast.[8]

Although the pilot was produced in colour, the [videotape](/wiki/Videotape
"Videotape") was wiped in the 1970s leaving only a 16mm [black-and-
white](/wiki/Black-and-white "Black-and-white") film
[telerecording](/wiki/Telerecording "Telerecording").[9] In 2009, the pilot
episode was restored to colour using the [colour
recovery](/wiki/Colour_recovery "Colour recovery") technique previously used
for the _[Dad's Army](/wiki/Dad%27s_Army "Dad's Army")_ episode "[Room at the
Bottom](/wiki/Room_at_the_Bottom "Room at the Bottom")". The restored colour
version was first shown on BBC2 on 1 January 2010 as part of a special _Are
You Being Served?_ night.

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

The series gained much of its popularity with TV viewers by "[pushing the
envelope](/wiki/Pushing_the_envelope "Pushing the envelope")" through its
deliberate-yet-subtle use of [risqué](/wiki/Sexual_suggestiveness "Sexual
suggestiveness") [visual gags](/wiki/Visual_gag "Visual gag"),
[innuendo](/wiki/Innuendo "Innuendo")-infused dialogue and cleverly-disguised
[sophomoric humour](/wiki/Sophomoric_humor "Sophomoric humor"). These comical
devices also attracted some mild criticism, in part for relying on sexual
[stereotypes](/wiki/Stereotype "Stereotype") and [double
entendres](/wiki/Double_entendre "Double entendre") – e.g., Mrs Slocombe
discussing her cat: "Animals are very psychic...the least sign of danger and
my [pussy](/wiki/Pussy#Female_genitalia "Pussy")'s hair stands on end".

John Inman's portrayal of Humphries' over-the-top antics and sharp-tongued,
witty responses, along with his trademark [catch-phrase](/wiki/Catch-phrase
"Catch-phrase") "I'm free!", were enthusiastically embraced by many audience
members, and the character evolved into a [gay icon](/wiki/Gay_icon "Gay
icon") in popular culture. Despite this, Inman pointed out that Mr Humphries'
true sexual orientation was never explicitly stated in the series, and David
Croft said in an interview that the character was not homosexual, but "just a
mother's boy".[10] In an episode of the spin-off _[Grace&
Favour](/wiki/Grace_%26_Favour "Grace & Favour")_, the character is further
described as neither a "woman's man" nor a "man's man" and as being "in
limbo".

The characters (Mr Humphries especially) sometimes broke the [fourth
wall](/wiki/Fourth_wall "Fourth wall") for comical effect.

### International
broadcasts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: International broadcasts")]

The series was shown in the United States on [PBS](/wiki/PBS "PBS") stations
and on [BBC America](/wiki/BBC_America "BBC America"), as well as in many
[Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations")
nations around the world. PBS first began airing it (on 24 stations) in 1987,
and viewership steadily climbed as more stations carried it. By the early
1990s, it had gained such a loyal following that American viewers of the show
formed fan clubs and were in large attendance wherever cast members made guest
appearances.

_Are You Being Served?_ aired in Canada late night on
[YTV](/wiki/YTV_\(TV_channel\) "YTV \(TV channel\)"). It also became available
to Canadian viewers on PBS station WNED (Buffalo). The show aired on Saturday
evening prime time from the mid 1980s to late 1990s.

The series was also extremely popular in Australia. It started on [ABC
Television](/wiki/ABC_Television "ABC Television") in 1974 and was repeated by
ABC in Australia several times.[11] By 1978 it had been acquired by the
commercial [Seven Network](/wiki/Seven_Network "Seven Network") who
successfully screened repeats of the program to audiences larger than those
who viewed it on the ABC.[12] _Are You Being Served?_ was ranked as the top
rated show on Australian television for 1978, being watched by 2,255,000
people in five cities.[13]

### _The Best of Are You Being Served?_
(1992)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: The Best of Are You Being Served? \(1992\)")]

Buoyed by the huge success of the series in the United States, [BBC
America](/wiki/BBC_America "BBC America") commissioned a special straight-to-
VHS compilation in 1992. Running at 78 minutes, _The Best of Are You Being
Served_ featured newly-shot scenes of Mr Humphries reminiscing with his
elderly mother, Annie, about his time working at Grace Brothers. Both roles
were played by [John Inman](/wiki/John_Inman "John Inman"). The additional
sequences were filmed in America, and directed by Don Hopfer.

## Spin-
offs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Spin-offs")]

In 1992, most of the original cast reunited for a spin-off show, titled
_[Grace& Favour](/wiki/Grace_%26_Favour "Grace & Favour")_ in Britain and
Australia, and _[Are You Being Served
Again!](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served_Again! "Are You Being Served Again!")_ in
the United States and Canada. It ran for two series.

### Film
version[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Film version")]

Main article: [Are You Being Served?
(film)](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served%3F_\(film\) "Are You Being Served?
\(film\)")

In 1977, as for many other popular
[British](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/British "wikt:British") sitcoms of
the time, including _[On the Buses](/wiki/On_the_Buses "On the Buses")_ , a
feature film was produced: the _[Are You Being
Served?](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served%3F_\(film\) "Are You Being Served?
\(film\)")_ film had the same characters and cast. It was set in the fictional
resort of Costa Plonka, in Spain. The film was an adaptation of the successful
stage version of the show, which played at the Winter Gardens Theatre,
Blackpool over the summer of 1976.

### Adaptations in other
countries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Adaptations in other countries")]

A US adaptation pilot episode called _[Beane's of
Boston](/wiki/Beane%27s_of_Boston "Beane's of Boston")_ aired on 5 May 1979 on
[CBS](/wiki/CBS "CBS"), but it did not make it to series.

An [Australian spin-
off](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served%3F_\(Australian_TV_series\) "Are You Being
Served? \(Australian TV series\)"), also called _Are You Being Served?_ , ran
for sixteen episodes from 1980 to 1981 on [Network Ten](/wiki/Network_Ten
"Network Ten"). It starred [John Inman](/wiki/John_Inman "John Inman") as Mr
Humphries, and Australian actors as copies of characters of the original
series ([June Bronhill](/wiki/June_Bronhill "June Bronhill") as a character
similar to Mrs Slocombe, [Shane Bourne](/wiki/Shane_Bourne "Shane Bourne") as
a character similar to Mr. Lucas, and so on). The show takes place in the
fictional Bone Brothers store, as "[Grace Bros.](/wiki/Grace_Bros. "Grace
Bros.")" was the name of an actual department store chain in Australia. While
most episodes were somewhat direct re-films of old scripts (with minor changes
like names), the first episode features a new start showing Mr Humphries
joining from Grace Bros, and a series 2 episode is completely original,
dealing with Mr Humphries' visa running out.

The Singaporean [MediaCorp](/wiki/MediaCorp "MediaCorp") sitcom _Can I Help
You?_ had a similar title and premise, and was described by former cast member
[Vernetta Lopez](/wiki/Vernetta_Lopez "Vernetta Lopez") as "_Are You Being
Served_ , minus the wonderfully filthy jokes".[14]

### 2016
revival[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: 2016 revival")]

In 2016, a one-off revival episode was broadcast, as part of BBC's celebration
of 60 years of television sitcoms.[15] It was set in 1988 with the original
characters, played by a new set of actors.

Captain Peacock was played by [John Challis](/wiki/John_Challis "John
Challis"), Mrs Slocombe by [Sherrie Hewson](/wiki/Sherrie_Hewson "Sherrie
Hewson"), Mr Humphries by [Jason Watkins](/wiki/Jason_Watkins_\(actor\) "Jason
Watkins \(actor\)"), Miss Brahms by [Niky Wardley](/wiki/Niky_Wardley "Niky
Wardley"), Mr Grainger by [Roy Barraclough](/wiki/Roy_Barraclough "Roy
Barraclough") (Grainger having come out of retirement "To spend less time with
his wife"), Mr Harman by [Arthur Smith](/wiki/Arthur_Smith_\(comedian\)
"Arthur Smith \(comedian\)"), and Mr Rumbold by [Justin
Edwards](/wiki/Justin_Edwards_\(actor\) "Justin Edwards \(actor\)").[16][17]
New characters in the show were Young Mr Grace's grandson – also called Young
Mr Grace – played by [Mathew Horne](/wiki/Mathew_Horne "Mathew Horne"), Miss
Croft – named as a tribute to series co-creator David Croft – played by
[Jorgie Porter](/wiki/Jorgie_Porter "Jorgie Porter"), and newcomer Mr Conway,
played by [Kayode Ewumi](/w/index.php?title=Kayode_Ewumi&action=edit&redlink=1
"Kayode Ewumi \(page does not exist\)"). The series was written by [Derren
Litten](/wiki/Derren_Litten "Derren Litten"). The BBC issued a press release
saying: "It's 1988 and Young Mr Grace is determined to drag Grace Brothers
into, well 1988, but he has a problem on his hands. Mr Humphries, Captain
Peacock, Mr Rumbold and Mrs Slocombe all seem to be stuck in another era. A
new member of staff, Mr Conway, joins the team but will he help shake things
up or will he just put a pussy amongst the pigeons?"[15]

The episode was aired in August 2016 to universally poor reviews for both the
writing and the acting.[18][19][20]

_Are You Being Served?_ featured humour based on sexual
[innuendo](/wiki/Innuendo "Innuendo"), misunderstandings, mistaken identity,
[farce](/wiki/Farce "Farce") and occasional [slapstick](/wiki/Slapstick
"Slapstick"). In addition, there were [sight gags](/wiki/Sight_gag "Sight
gag") generated by outrageous costumes which the characters were sometimes
required to wear for store promotions, and gaudy store displays frequently
featuring malfunctioning robotic mannequins. The show is remembered for its
prolific use of [double entendres](/wiki/Double_entendre "Double entendre").

The main humorous base of the series was a merciless parody of the [British
class system](/wiki/Social_structure_of_the_United_Kingdom "Social structure
of the United Kingdom"). This permeated almost every interaction and was
especially evident in the conversations between the maintenance men and the
ostensibly higher-class store personnel. The episodes rarely left the store,
and to parody the stereotype of the British class system, characters rarely
addressed each other by their first names, even after work, instead using
their formal titled names ("Mr", "Mrs", "Miss", or even "Captain"). When they
did address each other by their first names, it was usually either as an
aside, or often for comic effect (e.g. an underling addressing a superior).

### Main
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Main characters")]

Main article: [List of Are You Being Served?
characters](/wiki/List_of_Are_You_Being_Served%3F_characters "List of Are You
Being Served? characters")

  * **[Mrs Betty Slocombe](/wiki/Mrs._Slocombe "Mrs. Slocombe")** ([Mollie Sugden](/wiki/Mollie_Sugden "Mollie Sugden")) (Series 1–10), a senior sales assistant and head of the ladies' department. She is known for her changing hair colour and conversations about her cat, which she always refers to as her "pussy".
  * **[Miss Shirley Brahms](/wiki/Miss_Brahms "Miss Brahms")** ([Wendy Richard](/wiki/Wendy_Richard "Wendy Richard")) (Series 1–10), a young, attractive, working-class, [cockney](/wiki/Cockney "Cockney")-speaking junior sales assistant to Mrs Slocombe.
  * **Mr Ernest Grainger** ([Arthur Brough](/wiki/Arthur_Brough "Arthur Brough")) (Series 1–5), a 40-year veteran of Grace Brothers, a senior sales assistant and head of the gents' department, who often falls asleep on the job, is usually grumpy, and wears a measuring tape over his shoulders. Arthur Brough died before the filming of Season 6. 
    * **Mr Percival Tebbs** ([James Hayter](/wiki/James_Hayter_\(actor\) "James Hayter \(actor\)")) (Series 6), Mr Grainger's replacement. He retired after only one year in the men's department.
    * **Mr Harry Goldberg** ([Alfie Bass](/wiki/Alfie_Bass "Alfie Bass")) (Series 7), Mr Tebbs's replacement. Originally the junior salesman, he was quickly promoted to senior after proving to be a master salesman. Like Tebbs, Goldberg lasted only one year.
    * **Mr Grossman** ([Milo Sperber](/wiki/Milo_Sperber "Milo Sperber")) (Series 8), an expert shoe salesman, joined the gents' department, when some of the floor space was given over to shoes. He lasted only four episodes.
    * **Mr Abraham Klein** ([Benny Lee](/wiki/Benny_Lee "Benny Lee")) (Series 8), joined the gents' department to help out with upcoming sales in the store. Klein lasted only four episodes.
  * **[Mr Wilberforce Claybourne Humphries](/wiki/Mr_Humphries "Mr Humphries")** ([John Inman](/wiki/John_Inman "John Inman")) (Series 1–10), a sales assistant in gents'; a [campy](/wiki/Campy "Campy")-acting man who lives with his mother. He made frequent use of [double entendre](/wiki/Double_entendre "Double entendre"), especially related to his presumed [gay](/wiki/Gay "Gay") lifestyle.
  * **Mr James/Dick Lucas** ([Trevor Bannister](/wiki/Trevor_Bannister "Trevor Bannister")) (Series 1–7), the young, penniless, womanising junior salesman; a source of irritation to the female sales staff. Always referred to as the department 'junior', but Bannister was in fact one year older than Inman. The character left the series after Series 7 (1979). (In Series 2 his name was given as "James" but was stated as "Dick" in Series 5 and 6.) 
    * **Mr Bert Spooner** ([Mike Berry](/wiki/Mike_Berry_\(actor\) "Mike Berry \(actor\)")) (Series 8–10), eventually replaced Mr Lucas as gents' junior sales assistant and was similar to him in many ways.
  * **["Captain" Stephen Peacock](/wiki/Captain_Peacock "Captain Peacock")** ([Frank Thornton](/wiki/Frank_Thornton "Frank Thornton")) (Series 1–10), the haughty [floorwalker](/wiki/Floorwalker "Floorwalker") (an employee who both supervises sales staff and assists customers) who purportedly fought in the [North Africa Campaign](/wiki/North_Africa_Campaign "North Africa Campaign") of World War II but was accused of actually being in the [Service Corps](/wiki/Royal_Army_Service_Corps "Royal Army Service Corps") and never seeing combat.
  * **Mr Cuthbert Rumbold** ([Nicholas Smith](/wiki/Nicholas_Smith_\(actor\) "Nicholas Smith \(actor\)")) (Series 1–10), the autocratic, obsequious (to the Grace brothers), yet bumbling and incompetent floor manager.
  * **" Young" Mr Grace** ([Harold Bennett](/wiki/Harold_Bennett "Harold Bennett")) (Series 1–8), the very old, rich but stingy store owner, surrounded by attractive young women. The character's final appearance was in 1981 following Bennett's death. The character was killed off in the first episode of the spinoff series _[Grace& Favour](/wiki/Grace_%26_Favour "Grace & Favour")_. 
    * **" Old" Mr Grace** ([Kenneth Waller](/wiki/Kenneth_Waller "Kenneth Waller")) (Series 8), "Young" Mr Grace's even-older brother – replaced him at the store when he took a sabbatical to write his memoirs. In Series 9 & 10, the management of the store was again attributed to "Young" Mr. Grace, who was by then an invisible character.
  * **Miss Belfridge** ([Candy Davis](/wiki/Candy_Davis "Candy Davis")), the last and longest-running of Mr Rumbold's secretaries. She was admired by all male staff, including Mr Humphries and especially Captain Peacock, who dined her at [The Ritz](/wiki/The_Ritz_Hotel,_London "The Ritz Hotel, London").
  * **Mr Mash** ([Larry Martyn](/wiki/Larry_Martyn "Larry Martyn")) (Series 1–3), 
    * **Mr Harman** ([Arthur English](/wiki/Arthur_English "Arthur English")) (Series 4–10), the stock and maintenance men who installed mechanised display units in store and were both often scolded by Captain Peacock for being on the floor during opening hours.
  * **Diana Yardwick** ([Doremy Vernon](/wiki/Doremy_Vernon "Doremy Vernon")), the manageress of Grace Brothers' canteen at which the staff had their lunch. Known for serving grossly unappetizing food, and for her ill temper and sarcasm, as well as for enforcing strict social order, which dictated that management, sales staff and the maintenance crew and lift operators all dine separately.

## Theme
song[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Theme song")]

The theme song, written by the show's co-writer [David
Croft](/wiki/David_Croft_\(TV_producer\) "David Croft \(TV producer\)") and
composer [Ronnie Hazlehurst](/wiki/Ronnie_Hazlehurst "Ronnie Hazlehurst"),
consists of a [lift girl](/wiki/Elevator_operator "Elevator operator") (whose
voice was provided by Stephanie Gathercole) announcing each floor over the
_[musique concrète](/wiki/Musique_concr%C3%A8te "Musique concrète")_ sounds of
a [cash register](/wiki/Cash_register "Cash register") (which effectively
serves as the only percussion instrument) and a simple musical
[accompaniment](/wiki/Accompaniment "Accompaniment").

The 1977 _[Are You Being Served?](/wiki/Are_You_Being_Served%3F_\(film\) "Are
You Being Served? \(film\)")_ film has a different version of the theme song
which is longer, in a different key and without the floor announcements. A
remix of the theme was released in 1996 by a dance act calling itself "Grace
Brothers",[21] and featured vocal samples of John Inman and Frank Thornton.

There is a homage to the theme song in the [Ladytron](/wiki/Ladytron
"Ladytron") song "Paco!" from the album _[604](/wiki/604_\(album\) "604
\(album\)")_ , and New Zealand band [Minuit](/wiki/Minuit_\(band\) "Minuit
\(band\)")'s "I hate guns". A lugubrious version of the theme song is featured
on the album _[The Ape of Naples](/wiki/The_Ape_of_Naples "The Ape of
Naples")_ by the [experimental music](/wiki/Experimental_music "Experimental
music") group [Coil](/wiki/Coil_\(band\) "Coil \(band\)"). The theme song has
also been covered by Australian band [Regurgitator](/wiki/Regurgitator
"Regurgitator") on their 1999 album _[...art](/wiki/...art "...art")_. Pop
singer [Jamelia](/wiki/Jamelia "Jamelia")'s song "Window Shopping" (from her
2006 album _[Walk with Me](/wiki/Walk_with_Me_\(album\) "Walk with Me
\(album\)")_) begins with a sample of the familiar cash register sound effect
as well as Mrs Slocombe's voice inquiring, "Good morning, Mr Grainger; are you
free?"

The song was also used in a 2016 [Audi](/wiki/Audi "Audi") advertisement for
their [Quattro](/wiki/Audi_Quattro "Audi Quattro") range.

##
Merchandise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Merchandise")]

Seven early episodes were novelised for a book, written by Jeremy Lloyd,
called _Are You Being Served? – Camping In and other Fiascos_. This was
written in 1976, and republished in 1997 by _KQED Books_. The seven episodes
featured are _Camping In_ , _Up Captain Peacock_ , _Wedding Bells_ , _His and
Hers_ , _Coffee Morning_ , _The Hand of Fate_ and _The Clock_.

In 1995, KQED Books published _Are You Being Served – The Inside Story_ by
[Adrian Rigelsford](/wiki/Adrian_Rigelsford "Adrian Rigelsford"), Anthony
Brown, and Geoff Tibbals, with a foreword by Jeremy Lloyd, and sub-titled:
"The Inside Story of Britain's Funniest – and Public Television's Favorite –
Comedy Series". In 212 pages, the book's six chapters cover: The Cast of
Characters, Behind the Scenes, The Episodes, The Spin-offs, Trivia Quiz, and
Glossary. [ISBN](/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number "International
Standard Book Number") [0-912333-04-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-912333-04-9
"Special:BookSources/0-912333-04-9").

In 1999, _I 'm Free! The Complete Are You Being Served?_, a guide to the
series, was published by [Orion Books](/wiki/Orion_Books "Orion Books"). It
was written by Richard Webber, with contributions from David Croft and Jeremy
Lloyd.

A board game was also produced in the 1970s. Players moved round a board
resembling the shop floor to purchase one item from each of the four counters
and leave the store, before their opponents and without going over budget.

### DVD
releases[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Are_You_Being_Served%3F&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: DVD releases")]

All ten series, including a black and white version of the pilot episode, and
all five Christmas specials from those years, as well as both series of _Grace
& Favour_ are now available on DVD in the UK (Region 2). _Are You Being
Served?: the Movie_ was released in 2002. A colour-restored version of the
original pilot episode has yet to be released commercially.

All ten series, as well as both series of _Grace & Favour_ (in packaging
titled _Are You Being Served? Again!_) and the film are available on DVD in
Region 1 (North America).

All ten series, as well as both series of _Grace & Favour_ and the film have
been released in Australia (Region 4).

A DVD titled _Are You Being Served? – Best of The Early Years_ and _Are You
Being Served? Christmas Specials_ have also been released.
